user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of detect_process_cpu_core_count:
```c
static unsigned int
detect_process_cpu_core_count (void)
{
  unsigned int num_proc_cpu_cores;
  unsigned int sys_cpu_cores;
  int res;

  sys_cpu_cores = get_cpu_core_count ();
  res = mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count ();
  if (0 > res)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Cannot detect the number of logical CPU cores available "
             "for this process.\n");
    if (1 != sys_cpu_cores)
      printf ("Assuming all %u system logical CPU cores are available to run "
              "threads of this process.\n", sys_cpu_cores);
    else
      printf ("Assuming single logical CPU core available for this process.\n");
    num_proc_cpu_cores = sys_cpu_cores;
  }
  else
  {
    printf ("Detected %d logical CPU core%s available to run threads "
            "of this process.\n", res, (1 == res) ? "" : "s");
    num_proc_cpu_cores = (unsigned int) res;
  }
  if (num_proc_cpu_cores > sys_cpu_cores)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "WARNING: Detected number of CPU cores available "
             "for this process (%u) is larger than detected number "
             "of CPU cores on the system (%u).\n",
             num_proc_cpu_cores, sys_cpu_cores);
    num_proc_cpu_cores = sys_cpu_cores;
    fprintf (stderr, "Using %u as the number of logical CPU cores available "
             "for this process.\n", num_proc_cpu_cores);
  }
  return num_proc_cpu_cores;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No compiler language extensions are used in the provided code fragment. Specifically:

- There are no use of compiler-specific keywords or attributes such as __attribute__, __declspec, __asm, __builtin_*, __extension__, typeof, __inline (compiler-specific), or similar extensions.
- There are no GNU extensions like nested functions, statement expressions ({ ...; }) used as expressions, or designated initializers with non-standard syntax.
- There is no inline assembly, no pragmas that are compiler-specific, and no use of nonstandard calling-convention specifiers (e.g., __stdcall, __cdecl).
- The code uses standard C constructs only: function with prototype (void), standard storage-class specifier (static), ordinary integer types, casts, conditional (?:) operator, and standard library functions fprintf/printf. Adjacent string literal concatenation is a standard C feature.
- All format specifiers used (%d, %u) match the argument types (int and unsigned int respectively after cast), and casting of res to unsigned int is standard C.

Therefore there are no fragments that require investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (no language extensions detected).
